QuoteText: If I'm seeing the right photo, these eyes are in no way in the rear of the head. Although they do serve lateral vision because the insect has no neck and therefore is unable to turn its head. It must turn its whole body in order to advance its line of vision. So by what evidence do you claim this is the result of evolution and not original creation? Had the spider been at such a defensive loss prior to allegedly evolving the median eyes, how did it originally survive the millions of years needed to adapt? Especially in the radically environmentally unfriendly period in evolutionary history when this evolution process would have occurred? And why hasn't it continued to evolve more sophisticated vision in the hundreds of millions of years since then? All of these questions demand a rational answer before Creationism can be discounted out of hand.
ResponseText: That photo is looking at the four eyes on the front of its head. The diagram immediately above that photo on the website shows the location of the other four eyes, to the side and rear of the head: I have to ask: why did you present the supposed lack of animals with eyes in the backs of their heads as evidence against evolution, if the existence of animals with eyes in the backs of their heads isn't allowed to count as evidence for evolution? Well, assuming for the sake of argument that they even were spiders at the time they evolved their arrangement of eyes, the answer would be "Slightly less well" Seriously. Animals of the same species are competing against each other as well as the rest of the environment. Spiders hose out far, far more offspring than could possibly ever survive, so even a slight statistical advantage, over hundreds of generations, can transform the genetic profile of the species. Which makes the next useful mutation more likely to occur to a creature already possessed of the first mutation, so they stack. And so on. It doesn't have to be an all or nothing, survive or perish situation. Those are very rare. You probably drive a car to work, right? It's quite likely that a horse and cart would not meet your commuting needs. If we apply your logic from above, the advantage - even necessity - of cars in your modern way of life means horses and carts could never have existed! The mistake is obvious: we're holding too much constant. Horses and carts were once perfectly adequate - and still are in some societies. What makes you think it was any more hostile than now? What makes you think it hasn't ? It's never possible to discount special creation of all life, only to show that it's a loose and inelegant theory that doesn't make useful predictions. Special Creation is an explanation, Evolution is an explanation. The difference is that when we ask Creation 'what should we expect?' we get little more than a shrug. Creation means anything's possible. Evolution, on the other hand, is tightly bound by its own rules. We should never see a fossil of one of these creatures earlier than those creatures. We should never see this feature in that class of creature, because it evolved after evolution seperated them. If you have two sports anchors, and before the match one of them gives a detailed run-down of the teams' history and form, and expounds at length about what he expects the result of the game to be and how each player should perform, while the other says "Well, I definitely think one team will win; I expect the ball to be kicked quite a few times and there will certainly be some passing and some running." - whom do you respect more if all the predictions of both anchors prove to be accurate?

ResponseText: Yeah, I guess you loose to empirical evidence as well, since it's something you have to present. Evolution, Darwinian Naturalism... whatever you want to call it. QuoteText: These cells cannot be anything or produce anything other than what they are... in other words includes only the information to reproduce itself, ergo... human skin DNA cannot morph into liver DNA, so no fish forming legs, no apes flying planes or creating "higher order" intelligence. The whole of evolution is based on chance, chance as causality. Fully knowing that chance in itself is not agency - there is no causality in chance, chance is a byproduct of an event therefore cannot effect anything, so the equation would look something like: chance + any amount of time = nothing, therefore evolution or any of its pseudo-intellectual ilk are simply impossible.
ResponseText: So how do you explain the nylon bug? It can do something its ancestors could not - for the very simple reason that it's not the same as its ancestors. I smell an arcane semantics-based proof brewing... ...and I wasn't disappointed I don't know what 'chance as causality' is supposed to mean, but to speak of evolution being 'based on chance' is highly misleading. If I have an accident on the way to work tomorrow morning, there will be a definite cause; a specific series of events leading up to it. We cannot guess what they might be. Nevertheless, we can still makes statements about the statistical likelihood of such an accident occurring, yes? Does that accurate statement of probability mean that my fate on the road is literally determined by a dice roll, that if my number comes up, I crash, with 'chance as causality'? Of course not. We are merely describing the likelihood of an event in a system of which we have imperfect knowledge. As our knowledge of the system increases, our assessment of that likelihood changes: if you know my age and gender, my driving habits, my route and how busy or quiet it is - all these things permit a more accurate assessment of the odds. If we had perfect knowledge of a deterministic system, the odds would be 1 or 0. Similarly, every mutation that has ever occurred has had a definite proximate cause, and if we knew what they all were and what they would all be in the future, evolution would lie mapped out before us in all its detail. Nevertheless, in the absence of perfect knowledge of these individual causes we can still describe the occurrence of such events statistically, saying how long we might have to wait, or how many trials we might conduct in order to expect a given outcome. So to say that the evolution of the nylon bug, for instance, was based on chance is misleading: the evolution of the nylon bug was based on whatever proximate cause shuffled its DNA. Correctly viewed, evolution is not a series of unlikely events, but a series of highly likely ones. It is highly likely , for instance, that some bacteria in a large colony would experience a mutation enabling the digestion of nylon. Sure - breaking that event down on a per-bacterium basis yields tiny probabilities, but why stop there? Why not break it down on a per-bacterium, per-microsecond basis? The chances just got even smaller! See? It's a silly way to think about it, because in the end it's the chance of the event occurring that matters, not some arbitrary deadline by which it must occur or cell to which it must occur.
Say for a minute I am now convinced evolution has some problems and am doubting whether or not it is true. What evidence could you offer me that creationism is, in fact, the one true theory?

An example of quote mining - just the one, as I can't be bothered to do them all. Darwin and the Eye With regards to 'causality' - that's another argument entirely, and deals with abiogenesis and the Big Bang, not evolution. With regards to 'chance' - it is, indeed, misleading. No, believe me, you are illiterate, as you are incapable of actually writing a cogent sentence. You are ignorant, as you think that evolution means that a toenail can turn into an eye. And you posted quote mines (not "testimony"). Quote mines are quotes which have been removed from context, most often in an attempt to make it appear that the one being quoted is saying something completely different from what they actually said. A good example is the "Darwin-eye" quote mine, which iangb already addressed.
